newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: CRICKET-VETTORI SENDS NEW ZEALAND CRICKET INTO A SPIN.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-VETTORI SENDS NEW ZEALAND CRICKET INTO A SPIN.

text.p: Last year, Daniel Vettori was just another cricket-mad Kiwi schoolboy, who dreamed of playing for his country.
This year, the bespectacled 18-year-old left-armer, currently preparing for the Independence Cup one-day tournament in India, is New Zealand's leading spin bowler.
Vettori has been an immediate success since he was selected last February as New Zealand's youngest-ever test player.
"He's a wonderful talent," said former captain Martin Crowe, the best batsman in New Zealand's history.

"I would have had a lot of respect for him because he doesn't bowl bad balls. He's always there and you have to be patient with a bowler like that, play him with quality because he's giving you quality."
Vettori was thrown in at the deep end after New Zealand came back from the dead to salvage a draw against England in the first test.
"I'd be lying if I said we didn't cross our fingers," convenor of selectors Ross Dykes said at the time.
In a telephone interview, Vettori added: "It was a huge shock. But it was a good shock!"
The gamble paid off handsomly.
In just four tests -- two against England and two against World Cup champions Sri Lanka -- the teenager has taken 18 wickets at the impressive average of 23.8.

New Zealand eventually lost the first test series 2-0 to England, but Vettori's consistently accurate line and length, and his ability to turn the ball wickedly for a finger spinner, troubled the best of the English batsmen.
He set up a winning opportunity in the third test, taking four for 97 from a mammoth 58 overs in England's second innings.
Often extracting venomous spin from the rough, Vettori had Alec Stewart playing like a novice, at one stage striking Stewart in the face and drawing blood with a viciously rising ball.
It was no surprise when Stewart, the most prolific test scorer in 1996, offered a bat-pad catch off Vettori for 17.
That was only a glimpse of what was to follow.
The touring Sri Lankans followed England to New Zealand expecting to clean up in the two test matches and one-day games. They had not seen the Kiwis' new spin bowler.
Vettori took the wickets of Sri Lankan captain Arjuna Ranatunga and century-maker Romesh Kaluwitharana on a seamers' wicket in the first test as New Zealand cruised to an easy win.

In the second test, he was instrumental in an even more emphatic victory, taking his first five wicket bag in the second innings and a total haul of nine wickets in the game and winning the man-of-the-match award.
Perhaps Vettori's biggest strength is his cool head. He has been dubbed Jack Frost by his team mates.
"He's such a well-balanced kid. He doesn't appear to be too flustered by any of the hype that goes with test and one-day cricket," said New Zealand coach Steve Rixon.
Vettori admits to being "nerve-racked" when he was first called up to bowl against the likes of England captain Mike Atherton, but says he does not let the calibre of his opponents overawe him.
"I don't look at the actual player, I just look at him as a batsman that I'm bowling to. I mean, I know they're bloody good players, but I try not to let that enter my mind," he said.
Vettori's prospects seem limitless but he inevitably has much to learn in a trade where the top exponents are traditionally in their thirties before they reach their prime.
The selectors chose to omit him from the one-day internationals against England in order to ensure he remained an attacking bowler.
He played in the second one-day international against Sri Lanka but was taken out of the attack after conceding 21 runs in two overs.
Rixon is careful not to tempt the fates by over-praising his prodigy.
"But what I will say is I like what I see so far," Rixon said. "And I believe he is certainly part of New Zealand's cricket future."
